author: chewbaccaraty
body:
> If they were to stop all R&D and become purely a Falcon 9 and Falcon Heavy company, they'd still be at their current launch cadence and have the ability to undercut ULA and Boeing by selling services at 1/3 their competitors' cost.

Prove it.  We have no idea how much Falcon 9 costs, we only know what investor subsidized pricing looks like.  

>They're the only company in the world able to reuse orbital rockets. Beyond their technological achievements, the company's organization is the most valuable thing about it. Old Space companies are worse than car companies in their resistance to change.

Reusable is not necessarily cheaper.  See: the Space Shuttle

>Looking forward, they'll be the building the road to Mars with their mass production even if they get 1/10th their goal with Starship. They have the best methane engine in volume production, whereas Blue Origin is trailing and slow as shit.

Waaaaaay forward.  Like, you might not be around to see it.

author: Beastinlosers
body:
The problem with Netflix is that it's only good as long as people dont watch shows and buy a subscription. Well since lots of people share subscriptions across your family, and maybe friends this brings down potential clients.
Also it's not an ad based business so its ironically not really in their best interest for people to really watch it outside of releasing good content so people stay subscribed. Most of their video is stored in special servers at your ISP and other CDNs though, so it may not be an extremely big deal.
Edit: but yeah you're right, I bet people will look at the time spent on the service and call that a win.

author: dwmeds
body: Why DXC?

author: MSL0727
body:
Very very bad company. I went from HP to Hewlett-Packard Enterprise to DXC Technology, and the whole time we were employed at DXC there was a feeling of death around with no morale and a very sad feeling around the fact that most were told they should just be happy they have a job. Although I literally sat and watched as person by person around me all inevitably got laid off. They'd come in on Thursday and be told the next day (Friday) would be their last day and they'd be lucky to get severance. I eventually left the company because of anything could be better, and I was looking to grow and not be held down. 

No raises or bonuses for years, layoffs left and right, vile environment, etc. I wouldn't own it, but then again I don't track the stock price and I see it from a perspective that would never interest me in looking.

author: BattletoadRash
body:
Yea, I mean Lawrie is well know for being particularly draconian in his turnarounds. This has been 8 years in the coming, since Lawrie first joined CSC in 2012. 

His 1st course of action was completely revising the entire company's job title/salary structure, leading to a large exodus especially of VPs who were being demoted. (I left around this time).

2nd step was spinning off the govt business. 

3rd step was merging the commercial side with HPE.

4th was massive cuts and layoffs across the new DXC org.

5th was revamped M&A approach and sale of their less profitable business units. 

The guy is a dick for sure, but it's hard to argue with his results from a business perspective. 

Lawrie recently stepped down from the CEO role. With a new CEO, new business model, and new cash from the spinoffs, they may be positioned to become a respectable business again and grow... or sell.

author: BallsTreesDebts
body:
$30k is significant. I'd love to have $30k, but I don't because I'm poor. And that's why I'm giving investment advice on reddit...so... A lot of eggs in a few baskets is easier to watch than ten baskets. You can't effectively watch ten companies. You will have more luck getting to know two or three. You will also be more invested mentally. Putting $3k in ten companies doesn't make you more secure. It thins out your ability to pay attention effectively. Ten will make you emotional. You're focus will be split ten ways and you won't be making significant money from any of them. Focus on your best three or four ideas. Put $10k into Disney. Then wait another quarter and put another $10k into Disney. Wait another quarter and put the last $10k into Disney. ONE stock. Or you can buy some junior mining penny stocks like me. Up 50% since Thursday. This is speculation on the assumption that after a crash there is a mining boom. This is gambling. Disney is the real deal. Bank on Disney, put $3k into sphinx resources. You'll regret sphinx, but Disney will pay off until the day you're diagnosed with stage 4 cancer. Know what causes cancer? stress. You'll stress about ten small investments until you sell for some reason some day, or you'll feel secure in one good investment forever. 

Why DXC? because it's a spin off and Joel Greenblatt told me those can be lucrative. I'm a fan though. I want it to do well. I like DXC and Garrett... I own neither. There are at least seven companies I'd buy before those two. Six of them are Canadian banks. If I wanted a sure thing... If I wanted something that would exist in 50 years... something I could buy enough of so that their dividends afforded more shares of that company... something that creditors trust even in a crisis, something with a brand akin to a cult... something that just cannot fail... I'd buy Disney. It's only $30k. Buy Disney all through the recession. $30k worth of shares averaging down over the next year will pay off until you die. 

All those other choices are meh. Amazon might be a good one, but it's on top already. Tesla isn't profitable and they make cars. These other ones are not 50 year companies. They compete in competitive industries where competitive destruction reigns. Disney is different. In conclusions: spend $30k on apple.

author: BallsTreesDebts
body: Don't buy airlines. I hate all your positions except Disney. Just buy Disney. It's only $30k. Don't split it ten ways. Split it three ways. Buy Disney for the rest of your life. Don't buy these other ones. Warren Buffett was buying Apple right before the crash. Bet he's buying Apple now. Tesla isn't profitable. Carnival is evil. Amazon may be an okay idea... Look into DXC Technology. Look into VIAC. Look into WD-40. Or just buy Disney and Apple right now, and wait for a few months for the global economy to struggle. Buy again next quarter. Don't split $30k ten ways on those stocks. Focus on two or three.

author: -Bearaxe-
body:
I think...

TSLA, ENPH, SEDG and the solar and energy storage sector in general will feed on big oil dysfunction and current social sentiment moving in their favor.

Starlink IPO will be huge. Global high speed wifi service. Has a detailed YouTube video

Whichever mining company gets the opportunity to expand their tech to push asteroid mining resources via partnership with spacex or [space race winner]. Jeff Bezos has already created a sol system shipping infrastructure plan to mine the Kuiper belt. 

Work from home enterprises will gain steam. MSFT, ZM 

SQ is likely to do very well attempting to keep small businesses and contractors in the game with fluid mobile commerce.

Drone services. Specifically in CAD mapping and in tandem with a.i., drone software will replace many jobs. I'm a bridge inspector and already they are used often, with many of us realizing we won't have field work in the next few years. Drones are just too cheap, eliminating high insurance premiums and creating greater proof of work/protection against negligence claims.

Virtual and augmented reality will push into daily routines with further adoption of wearable technology and advancement of micro sensors. I don't know who is in the lead in this sector, but Neuralink scares the poo outta me. Like that's an idea straight out of the book of revalation... also has a detailed YouTube video if you want to see legit mind reading brain chips.

These are things I just see as inevitable outcomes in a further corporatized world that is constantly seeking to hedge against liability and produce greater efficiency from an increasingly distracted workforce. The sci-fi channel has arrived.

author: 4121Laurel
body:
No although you’re very invested in technology
Which isn’t a bad thing.  
- AAPL is great, their market value will always go back to what it was even if they don’t release the new iPhone. Don’t be afraid of a drop just average costs if it drops dramatically. 

- Adobe should do well with this stay at home. School is requiring the use as well as businesses from home. 

- Amazon is essentially showing its untouchable currently. I’m large into amazon as well. 

- Disney is another powerhouse that you’ll never need to worry about. The lost revenues over the following 8 months could cause a dramatic drop, in this scenario don’t panic and average your cost. 

- Enph - energy, I’m not familiar with this company. 

- Facebook is another powerhouse good pick. 

- Google - Great pick. 

- MasterCard is also a good pick, hold this. Average if it comes down to although you shouldn’t have to they trade rather high. If you’re at a major loss with their recent decline. Average in the next 3 months when there’s a better understanding how financials will deal with crisis. (You shouldn’t need to) 

- Microsoft - I love microsoft. They are on a tear currently. Teams daily usage is up 12 million users in the last month, this is major. Their competition is “work” slack technologies who I am also Long. 

- Netflix has been great good pick. 

- Nike is a great pick. I could expand but they’ve always done well. Constant increase throughout the life of their stock. 

- Nvidia is a powerhouse as well. Great pick. 

- Starbucks is great. I haven’t followed them through the virus but they’re a strong company large capital, their profits are also great. Good pick. 

- Square I like square a lot. Square has major potential in different avenues. Cash app, lending (they just got approved to lend during this time). Prior to the virus square was on a tear. I’m long on this I got in early and am very big on square. 

If you’re interested in diversification:

All that being said you really are big into tech, I would suggest diversification. 

“Oxy” - occidental petroleum is a good long term stock. They’re trading extremely low currently due to oil wars, corona virus, issues on the board and the purchase of anadarko. (This scares a lot of investors but you seem to want long term investments) it’s a steal at 15$ a share. 

- Johnson and Johnson is a powerhouse. 

- Jet blue & Delta - long term great investments. Short term extremely risky. 

- Walmart: trading high but they’re only going to go even higher when this is over. 

- AT&T and Verizon: AT&T trades fairly low with a large dividend. GREAT LONG TERM. Verizon has been extremely strong throughout the years.  

- Ford on the long term has a lot of upside trading around half of its average price. Ford pays dividend and  history has proven America will never let ford fail. 

- USO is an ETF that tracks United States Oil, It’s trading extremely low, no reason not to diversify with this. ( The oil war between Saudi and Russia is coming to an end, this should do well in the long term) 

- Have you put any though into mutual funds to also diversify ? A good managed funds typically has large returns and low risk. 

Reach out to me if you’d like.

author: Firmest_Midget
body:
I also think there will be additional price declines, and plan to get more at those later times. If you're getting ENPH, be sure to also get SEDG. As I'm sure you're aware, they both manufacture solar DC/AC inverters, but they take different approaches to the tech, and actually occupy different niches within the solar world. Combined, these two make up 80% of the North American solar market - which is still expected to grow by 20% this year, despite the pandemic.  

My company brokers wind and solar Power Purchase Agreements. Our clients want renewable power, and we make it happen for them, sending out RFPs to developers and getting their project bids. We get a fee from our clients for brokering these projects. We also finance solar projects ourselves so that we own the power - this is a steady source of revenue for the life of the solar system. We closed ~$270mil of on-site solar deals in the last month. All of our clients have affirmed that they still wish to proceed with their projects, and there is no percepitble drop in interest in this sector. All systems are green!

author: fancykevin00
body:
I'm kinda in the same position as you.  Long Puts May to July. I was confused as hell and started reading and researching and ran across a chart earlier tonight. For me it was eye opening.

I was looking at the economy and saying the market has to go down, we are in some deep shit and the economy will have hell to pay.  

I started with 4k and got to 80ish k - I was ahead of everyone and even re-balanced 80% of my 401k to bonds and treasuries, well ahead of the big drop.  I bought put option on AMC, looking back I wasnt smart enough to do the SPY...LMAO - you live you learn

A week ago I was Laid Off and I am determined to grow the house money, what is now left on the table about $35k.

I got luck a few more times and got to $80k - 1/3 is already in savings and so only house money on the table. Mostly tied in puts and a few LEAPS.  My dumb luck, I have SPY puts and puts on gold, unfortunately, both went in the same direction...UP

This Chart is what caught my eye and I realized the Fed will hold the market up as long as needed and will let the economy play catch up.  They were not this aggressive previously 2008-2009 and not this quick to act.  

Holding the market up will accelerate the recovery as in keep jobs on the table?

[https://i.imgur.com/3NLR9rx.png](https://i.imgur.com/3NLR9rx.png)

Look at 1/3/2008 and see the market drop...

Look at 1/3/2018 then by 12/2018 there was a huge flash crash, the Fed trend continued then 2/2020-3/2020 the market followed the Fed's balance sheet.  With the Fed's spike up via unlimited QE, we may gradually start going down but over a longer period of time and maybe not as much.  Fed acted like an Airbag.

 I fear I may not have enough time in my May-June puts.  Hence I am lowering my Put positions in those months and going to cash with a few calls.  I am not certain this will happen, but can tell there is something artificial holding this up.  Even Ackerman got out and is now bullish but isnt shouting it like he normally does on EVERYTHING. Not that I like the guy, but he seemed spooked and is refusing comments on a lot of things.  Being quiet is not his norm.

I am now looking instances in history to see how unlimited QE has worked out, not able to find anything where the QE was to this magnitude.  As I type this, I realize I found an answer to a question I have not thought to ask.   What are ALL the variables in determining why my puts could be wrong and do I understand the variables?

I am NOT saying I am right or wrong, but I found some sense of direction. 

Just wanted to share because I feel we are in the same boat and I'm in my last year of my 30's.

I dont have nearly enough savings and started late in my 401k - gotta make the best of it

I'm a self taught investor with plenty left to learn, so if you have any pointer, please share.  

Random rant: I feel our generation is one of the worst generations to be alive: Gulf War, .com bust, September 11, War in Iraq, the financial crisis, multiple large hurricanes, F5 tornadoes,  global warming and now a third recession that came with a fucking plague.

But we did get iphones and now we use them to trade stocks.

Cheers

author: whithercanada
body:
Huh?  Here's a rundown of what goes on in Germany, in case you won't read things outside of WSB (and honestly who could blame you?)

* People stay at home
* They get paid
* They pay bills and buy food because... they got paid
* They don't have to F5 a crashing website to apply for unemployment
* A year later, they're not competing for a Starbucks barista job against twelve schmucks with dual master's degrees
* Oh yeah, they're not driven to work (private chauffeurs are rare in Germany)

Downside: harder to pump bailout money directly into shareholders' veins

author: Mpcars
body: Look for short term moves that you expect will play out in 1-2 days. The money rn is all in the short term swings. Don’t buy anything long term. IV will kill you. If you see a stock stagnant for too long (3 days+) jump on it because nothing will every stay that way. I noticed that with UNH, V, and IBM yesterday, before the selloff today. The tighter the consolation, the bigger the move. Don’t try and ride the in-between movement. It’s usually garbage on the options and hard to time. Just wait until you feel it’s ready to break out of its range and boom you’ll make an easy 300%+.

author: mechtech
body:
You should be writing cash covered puts if this is your entry method.

If you're picking a fixed price and not taking in a premium in exchange for the hour-to-hour uncertainty, then I can't say I agree at all with this method.

I've been active trading this market since the peak and there have been days where I've flattened my account three separate times in the course of a single market session. Some days have more price discovery action and more game changing news than entire weeks had during the previous low-vix periods. If you're picking a price (which seems arbitrary to begin with, but let's assume it's a price perfectly in the middle of the "fair" price for your investment portfolio), then it's a distinct possibility that the assumptions that went into choosing the price are very out of date within even 24 hours.

I'd rather just scale in over a fixed period of time and not fixate on specific price points. And again, if you do have a fixed entry in mind, then write puts on that strike. You will get paid for the implied uncertainty that propagates out over the time period that you choose the entry price to the expiration date. I did this for IBM @ 90 a few weeks back (because I was 100% on board with buying IBM at 90 even if the bottom fell out of the market and SPY went to 2k), and picked up 4 bucks for it. That's a 5% discount on entry if it executed, and since it's not going to execute it's simply a decent chunk of money in exchange for just for committing to the offer to buy at 90.

author: peter-doubt
body:
This is a nasty market. But you're learning. 

Expect losses, unfortunately this was big. From one of my hardships, I may be abled to offer encouragement.  I bought (decades ago) IBM at a cheap $85/ share. The last cash I had. It promptly went down. Not a big deal, just $65. Then the floor dropped out... to $40.  

I said 'damn! no more cash to add... this is too cheap.'  So I kept my holdings and it slowly rebounded .. over the years to $180. With dividends I was made whole... Doubled my start in about 5 years... Could have (with better timing) been 5x. But this time I was happy greed didn't discourage me and prompt me to sell for less.

Lesson: take a stand, stay *informed* and don't quit unless you learn you're wrong. (Don't be blockheaded to not realize a mistake, either).

author: Myraxx_
body:
no, thats only when it expires at or above the strike. when it expires it can be exercised by the buyer and youre forced to sell at whatever strike that was. in my case, if i had held on to my IBM 115 4/9 covered call (sell to open) until expiration, i would've been fucked out of the additional dollars per share the stock climbed past the strike. in my case, it hit the strike, i bought myself out of the covered calls, then sold my long position (underlying) at a few dollars past strike (this is called unwinding). 

the alternative is rolling the call, which is to buy to close the covered call position and immediately selling another covered call at a higher strike for the same expiration.

author: tryexceptifnot1try
body:
Great post as always. So I have been in the finance industry for over a decade and have been a part of a risk modelling data science team for more than 5. What is the best way to determine what the swap players are using for risk modelling?  


I ask this because I have seen some truly awful risk modelling in this industry. Like if you interact with the Fed about CCAR issues you realize they are basically running models that sucked 10 years ago (logistic regression on severely limited time series data) on software that has sucked for 20 years (SAS). So outside of going to conferences and meeting these folks in person I need to find a way to figure out what they are generally using to predict. Are there some regulatory filings that are public domain that I can just CTRL+F for shit like "AI" and "IBM Watson AI"?

Rx. IBs in advisory charge multiples of what B4 does. Hell, just pull the 2019 debtwire report and see that A&M/Alix/FTI charges double/hr vs. B4. Rx. advisory also, in many circumstances, gets paid either weekly or in advance.

Depending on what B4 you are at, the "advisory" practices can be a pretty shitty mix between trying to compete with MBB, Rx. firms, IBs, etc. and really just being a master of selling their brand name vs. value add. Honestly, B4s at the moment are pretty much the definition of the "nobody ever got fired for buying IBM" quote that people often reference.

author: Senno_Ecto_Gammat
body:
That chart is misleading. The Dow Jones index is a crappy index for a lot of reasons, but one of them is that the people that run it keep fiddling with it, dumping some companies and adding others. Those decisions sometimes have bad results. In 1939 they dropped IBM from the index right before it made a meteoric rise. If they would have kept the index static, it would have shown a recovery much sooner, because the market recovered much sooner. DJIA is not an index used by serious people. 

http://archive.is/DvBPs

author: precrime3
body:
**Thoughts on APT Calls?**

**Original** \- Entered a call debit spread $11/$13 @ $0.98. Exp: 4/9 Reason I did a spread and not naked was due to lack of capital at time being.

I'm new to TA but wanted to try using what seem to be the most intuitive indicators for me - RSI, VWAP, and 50/200 MA.

**My DD**

When I entered the position, RSI seemed good but has gone up to 56 now, so that's got me a little bit worried.

However, APT has crossed and come over the 50MA line 3 times in the last 5 days, which I read now as a support rather than a distance. It has also directly bounced off the 200MA which is good to see as well.

Market EOD was $18.xx or so, but VWAP is around $15\~. Perhaps a good entry tomorrow for a long position will be if it returns to VWAP, but regarding the explosiveness and nature of the stock I'm also debating just buying ASAP with expiry for next week.

As for the strike price I'm looking at, I'm looking at around $25/26, which is where it peaked last time in early march.

**Sentiment** \- Talks about Americans getting used to the idea of having to wear masks. The thing is 3M, DuPont, etc. make PPE (personal protection equipment) but really APT has been sort of the front man of that for a while now. 

With fear going to spike up again this week, I think it'll be good to get in and take a long. Plus volume was only 20 million today, so hasn't been "discovered" by the media yet. 

Any tips/advice for a newbie would be very beneficial.

author: Nutmasher
body:
So looking at it on a 2 min, this recent bottom and churn at 2445-2525 has exposed the weakness of this technique.
MA crossovers do not fair well in sideways markets unless you scalp... Get out before the turn.
Even my 10-40 sma crossover gives false signals.
Obviously, the goal is to ride some wave higher.  It's coming today or next week, but this week, using this method is a bust.
I bought a 5% position in SSO Wednesday at a crossover signal (~2500), but ended up holding it vs selling on a down signal.  I did that because I knew price would cover back to this level.  Then, as prices hit the 78.6% retracement, I added another 5%.  O added a third 5% on another retracement Thursday.
I held these 3 positions until Thursday pm.  Sold for $2000 gain.

So it was a combination of...
1. Moving average crossover entry.
2. Dollar cost averaging on retracements.
3. Fib levels for entry.
4. Double top level for exit (Thursday high).

A lot more work than the casual investor is looking for.  But if I strictly followed the buy/sell at the signal, I would have lost money.  Probably the same $2000.

author: HockeyCoachHere
body:
Reasonable options, but they all have notable downfalls.

One of the big ones is that a centralized blockchain will never suffice to replace something like Visa.

The current international transaction rate of credit cards peaks around 25,000 per second (christmas eve of 2019) combining major brands (visa, mastercard, etc)

Cash is probably significantly higher than that worldwide.

For a currency to "replace" money or credit cards or banks, as the long-term stated goal of crypto enthusiasts, it has to scale to numbers on the order of thousands of transactions per second.

Bitcoin, Zcash and Monero as they are designed, are all fundamentally centralized public blockchains that implement various forms of anonymization for wallet transactions.  

However, in reality, it's probably not practical for all nodes to know about all transactions everywhere in the world at all times.   That requirement fundamentally means that every node everywhere has to constantly consume 5-20mbps of incoming transaction data, 24/7/365 and that's assuming no significant growth in transaction volumes.

Even with aggressive pruning of transactions, the volume of data to accurately summarize the net worth of 7 billion people plus their various businesses, teams, organizations, accounts and otherwise would be extraordinary (trillions of transactions, at least - possibly a petabyte of data).

In the current blockchain concept, any transactions that have any significant notable value to the network have to be recorded on this chain, or they can't be verified.  Concepts like lightening network on bitcoin can "shard" some of this off, but these side transactions are fundamentally unverified, and the money used in them is fundamentally locked out of the main wallet of anyone using these channels, making them practical for certain activities (say, buying some gum), but impractical for something like transacting your rent, or any other dollar value that you value.

Some concepts of more broad global sharding of the main chain exist, but under "proof of work" that doesn't really work well without establishing "trusted nodes" to referee the sharding and that doesn't make the decentralization proponents happy.

It's probably possible to design something, maybe using a proof of stake system with stakeholders pooled into smaller shards, but that runs a greater risk of having network takeovers, unless you have a referee system that patrols for large movements of stakeholders into shards in order to pool stakes and subvert the voting system for monetary gain.

It's not a solved problem and no platform currently exists that could plausibly take over world currency transactions, or even a smaller credit card player like Discover, in terms of size and volume.

Proof of work, in my opinion, is a poor tech and while I play in crypto as a speculative instrument, I view it like a penny stock in a worthless industry from a true fundamentals perspective.

But that's just my educated opinion.
